reviews.text: Disney-Pixar's best at least since Toy Story 3.
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: After its spectacular visuals and music, its true and celebrational inclusion of Mexican culture; what stays with us about COCO, is the loving heart of a family, and the strength of a little boy who won't give up his dream.
reviews.author: Diva Velez

reviews.text: A beautiful ode to the love of family.
reviews.author: Ashley Menzel

reviews.text: Besides being the first great Pixar movie about Hispanics, Coco is the best film about Alzheimer's since Marjorie Prime and Away From Her.
reviews.author: Tim Appelo

reviews.text: This turns out to be a very heartwarming story about family and the ending is quite emotional. The golden touch of Pixar and executive producer John Lasseter is evident here.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Enter Coco, a movie that has both Pixar's knack for the timeless, and that couldn't feel more timely and culturally important in the moment.
reviews.author: Brad Keefe

reviews.text: American films often are accused of either making a caricature of the minorities or of dumbing down their culture, their traditions. Coco thankfully escapes both allegations.
reviews.author: Devesh Sharma

reviews.text: Coco is a fun, touching movie, one that takes joy in the culture it depicts and invites viewers from other cultures along for the party, in ways both respectful and educational.
reviews.author: Abby Olcese

reviews.text: A nearly complete triumph, with a distinctive look, truly virtuoso animation, and a compelling, tear-jerking story
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: There are not enough superlatives for this film. It's a masterpiece.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: The work on screen is tireless, spinning a loving and immersive tale of memories, familial love and gratitude and the importance of holding onto where you've come from while forging your own path."
reviews.author: Allyson Johnson

reviews.text: Lee Unkrich and his co-director Adrián Molina did their documentation work well, especially when it comes to recreating the Day of the Dead both visually and spiritually. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Irene Crespo

reviews.text: Lee Unkrich's animated drama makes good use of its Mexico setting.
reviews.author: Nandini Ramnath

reviews.text: With as simple dramatic structure and a deep emotional canvas, is 2017 best animated film and Pixar's most beautiful feature film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: Kids under about 7 or 8, not to mention squeamish parents, might be freaked out by a few things rarely discussed or seen in animated films.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: In fact, as unlikely as this may seem, you'll find yourself thinking of this movie long after it's ended.
reviews.author: Dipanjan Sinha

reviews.text: The visuals of Coco are amazing from the bridge of flowers to the world of the dead. It's clear that Pixar took great care in getting Latin culture perfect.
reviews.author: Alan Ng

reviews.text: The film represents a full embrace of a culture and its people, as well as a celebration of family, both present and past. As such, it's difficult to imagine healthier holiday fare.
reviews.author: Michael Burgin

reviews.text: Directors Lee Unkrich and Adrian Molina, helped out by writers Jason Katz and Matthew Aldrich and a full-size city of technicians and crew, hit the right chords, gracefully.
reviews.author: Kelly Vance

reviews.text: As bright and colorful as it is, Coco feels more than a bit cut-and-pasted from previous Pixar efforts.It's not enough that much of Pixar's competition steals its formulas, it's as if the company is left having to pillage itself.
reviews.author: Piers Marchant

reviews.text: I feel a little better about my own mortality after seeing Coco; apparently all I need to do to live forever is make sure the living keep remembering me.
reviews.author: Jenni Moore

reviews.text: It's no exaggeration to say it shows us things we've never seen before, something that happens so rarely in modern cinema.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: Of every Pixar film that deals with family, memory, and loss, ask, "Is there sufficient reason for the tears that will inevitably run down my face by the end?" Yes, thanks in no small part to the ingenious use of De La Cruz's hit song, "Remember Me."
reviews.author: Matthew Lickona

reviews.text: ...a blunt, manic film that is worthy of Pixar's award-winning canon, but not as important as it should have been.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: Does Coco rise to the heights of Pixar's very best work? No. But it is a generous, heartfelt film, full of color and music, one that offers a timely Thanksgiving tribute to the intergenerational importance of family.
reviews.author: Christopher Orr

reviews.text: A wonderful animated feature set around the Day of the Dead in Mexico.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: Another creative Pixar/Disney character and critter movie. Never had the Land of the Dead had more life.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: You'll go cuckoo for "Coco."
reviews.author: Al Alexander

reviews.text: [O]ne of Pixar's all-time greats, a marvelous achievement worth experiencing with your whole family.
reviews.author: Mark Hughes

reviews.text: The film builds to an emotional tribute... that brings to mind the opening sequence of another Pixar triumph, Up.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: A beautiful love letter to México, its people and its culture, from Cantinflas to El Santo . One of Pixar's best of the decade. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mario Alegre

reviews.text: "Coco" is ravishing and almost seductive in the way it entices you. Not sure we've done enough good in our world to deserve such a gem. Open your heart to its excellence.
reviews.author: Clayton Davis

reviews.text: Add... its magical array of visuals - an entire "Land of the Dead" is realized - and its kind, loving representation of Mexican culture, and "Coco" becomes a force for good in the world.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: It's delightful stuff, made no less delightful by the darkness, most of which is handled so frankly that one simply grows accustomed to it.
reviews.author: Allison Shoemaker

reviews.text: Forgiveness and love are but two sides of the same peso.
reviews.author: Marc Savlov

reviews.text: Pixar's transcendent fable Coco is filled with visual wonders
reviews.author: Bennett Campbell Ferguson

reviews.text: None of Coco's few flaws can fatally undermine the film because it is, most of all, a smart and enduring piece of storytelling with a satisfyingly twisting narrative and richly complex theme.
reviews.author: Kate Taylor

reviews.text: You know the writing is solid when animated characters can touch your heart so deeply that a tissue is needed.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: Coco is an improvement, drawing upon magic realism and dizzying technical detail to create an immersive entertainment that never condescends to its audience.
reviews.author: Alan Zilberman

reviews.text: The movie's so enthralling that you won't even notice the emotional currents building steadily and powerfully underneath - until it wallops you with them, of course.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: Still, what really blew me away about Coco is the historic but long-overdue feat of being the first-ever movie with an all-Latino voice cast. It paid off.
reviews.author: Arianna Davis

reviews.text: This bright and mostly entertaining Coco honors Mexico.
reviews.author: Richard von Busack

reviews.text: Coco is worthwhile, just not as much so as I honestly hoped it would be.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: ... savor the sights and sounds of this latest Pixar win, achieved in unique fashion.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: This engaging Pixar animation plays magnificently with elements of Mexican folklore and fine art.
reviews.author: Ben Sachs

reviews.text: The film, despite its ostensibly creepy trappings, is a good, if not great, run through the standard Pixar formula that is bolstered by its distinct visual style and the long-overdue expansion of its cultural palette.
reviews.author: Peter Sobczynski

reviews.text: Some of the darkest ideas ever to manifest in a Disney-Pixar film take center stage in Coco, a movie that magically doubles as the studio's most colorful, vibrant adventure yet.
reviews.author: Melissa Leon

reviews.text: To call Coco dark would be too easy and also a disservice because it's one of the famed animated studio's most hopeful movies.
reviews.author: Gabrielle Bondi

reviews.text: ... both amusing and touching, using a celebration of death to prompt a fresh perspective on life.
reviews.author: Todd Jorgenson

reviews.text: The overarching themes of "Coco" might seem a bit basic for our high expectations of Pixar, but they are executed with heart and sincerity throughout the film.
reviews.author: Matthew Passantino

reviews.text: ...could be placed on an ofrenda as an offering of its own.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: The land of the dead, as imagined in Coco, is a glittering steampunk Metropolis of futuristic high-rises and magical bridges, populated with some of the cutest and most playful skeletons you've ever seen.
reviews.author: Sarah Boslaugh

reviews.text: A magical experience from the first frame through the final credits, it's a resonant fable that speaks to the heart of the young and old alike.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: The plot, arguably, comes packed with more complications and psychedelic spirit-critters than it really needs. But you can't blame Pixar's animators for having a field day with the film's imagery ...
reviews.author: Bob Mondello

reviews.text: It's a whimsical, touching and heartfelt celebration of Mexican traditions and folklore, and it's one of the more original stories the acclaimed animation studio has told in years.
reviews.author: Britton Peele

reviews.text: Coco is easily the best original property Pixar has come up with in roughly a decade.
reviews.author: Thaddeus McCollum

reviews.text: Pixar movies always look good, butCocois in a class by itself. Ablaze with eye-popping color, every widescreen frame is filled with richly detailed settings and appealing characters. This film is truly a celebration
reviews.author: Leonard Maltin

reviews.text: The Land of the Dead is one of Pixar's most enchanting worlds, unabashedly ethnic, filled with details you'll never be able to catch in a single viewing.
reviews.author: Rain Jokinen

reviews.text: The best animated offering of 2017. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Scary Scenes, etc. - also Available)
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: Not only do Coco's plot twists work like bone-shaking magic when they're finally revealed, but the way its musical and familial themes are woven together like the world's warmest serape earns enough emotional waterworks to flood the Sonoran Desert.
reviews.author: Bob Strauss

reviews.text: Pixar is back. Charming, vibrant, prepare to buy your kid a guitar.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: What makes Coco rare is that it recognizes that the things that give your life meaning might be in opposition to one another, and asks you to consider what really matters most.
reviews.author: Angie Han

reviews.text: Pixar returns stronger than ever with a magical and visual treat that will tug at your heartstrings.
reviews.author: Shyama Krishna Kumar

reviews.text: In total, Coco is a beautiful movie that has been cared for deeply.
reviews.author: Shea Serrano

reviews.text: True to Pixar form, Coco enhances its strong storytelling with brilliant visuals that inspire the imagination and, in this case, celebrate the Mexican culture.
reviews.author: Josh Terry

reviews.text: Coco is a bold and colorful animated dazzler of a movie with a story of family that goes straight to the heart of young and old alike, which means it's the kind of movie that Pixar used to make.
reviews.author: Michael Smith

reviews.text: The liveliest movie of the season is about dead people: Pixar Animation Studio's new movie Coco, a joyous celebration of memory linking our past to our present.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: The movie may encourage youngsters to ponder the perils of succumbing to the blinding light of celebrity and it shows -- in obviously literal fashion -- that there's much to be gained from honoring and remembering those who have gone before us.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: It's the kind of story Pixar has told before, but there's enough variation to make it feel fresh.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: Coco's flaws and limitations would sting less if it weren't the one original Pixar film in a string of sequels...With each new release it seems clearer that Pixar's glory days are an increasingly distant memory.
reviews.author: Steven D. Greydanus

reviews.text: Pixar rebounds nicely with Coco, a big, spangly animated fiesta with its fair share of "heart."
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: Coco wonderfully explores familial themes, identity, and learning what it means to grow up in a world that isn't perfect.
reviews.author: David Griffin

reviews.text: Enchanting and dazzling, Coco is a resplendent love letter to Mexico.
reviews.author: Claudia Puig

reviews.text: An imaginative, fun, charming trip filled with so much heart it (mostly) makes up for the fact that it's taking us someplace we've been before.
reviews.author: Joshua Starnes

reviews.text: Pixar's Day-of-the-Dead gem pays loving tribute to Mexican culture with animation that brims over with visual pleasures, comic energy and emotional wallop.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: The film is a visually gorgeous tapestry of Mexican culture and it fills the screen with the colourful vibrancy of Dia de Muertos.
reviews.author: Boon Chan

reviews.text: Coco is the most sentimental film offered by the Disney-Pixar canon since the 2010 release of Toy Story 3.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: "Coco" is magnificent storytelling! It honors families everywhere and the importance of being remembered by them.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: It's not a stretch to speculate that this movie --- while a lock for a Best Animated Feature nomination --- is a legitimate contender for Best Picture.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: 'Coco' has a big heart. It's an embracing experience that stresses not only the importance of family, but of heritage - of who your ancestors are and why they made the choices they did.
reviews.author: Bob Bloom

reviews.text: Pixar's heartfelt tribute to Mexico. Also, the best animated film of the year. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: Brimming with life, rich cultural heritage, dazzling color, beautiful music, and incomparable animation, [this is] a celebratory affair that's bound to strike the right chord.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: If you want to know whether or not your kid is creepy, ask them what lesson they learned from Coco.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: A harmonious set of themes, about vocation and ambition...the role of family...and the meanings of life and death.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: It has the dazzling visuals, expert tone and pacing, and the smiling-through-tears moments we have come to rely on from Pixar.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: There's a lot about 'Coco' that feels familiar...but the visual splendor certainly makes it an enjoyable confection, with the Latino ambiance an added bonus.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: The colorful visuals are matched with lively music, especially de la Cruz's signature song, "Remember Me."
reviews.author: Jody Mitori

reviews.text: "Coco" worked on me in ways I hadn't expected.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: It packs a couple of "didn't see that coming" moments, and closes with an obligatory family reunion emanating such joyous emotion, its deficiencies earn our forgiveness as well.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: In the end, it's all too much, yet at the same time not enough. Despite its efforts, Coco can't rise above mid-tier Pixar.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: "Coco" is the perfect reminder of why Pixar needs to continue to make original films, too, as it creates a vivid, colorful, and truly imaginative world based off the Mexican holiday of Dia de Muertos, otherwise known as the Day Of The Dead.
reviews.author: Gregory Wakeman

reviews.text: ... the film is exuberant and heartfelt, and the hero's journey takes him through spectacular territory...
reviews.author: Joe Morgenstern

reviews.text: Coco settles into something gentler but still irrefutably sweet: a movie that plays safe with the status quo, even as it breaks with it.
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: You will be taken to unimaginable places where humans and spooky creatures collide as they live in two parallel universes.
reviews.author: Dwight Brown

reviews.text: Pixar proves with its 19th feature film that not only has it not lost its touch, it's getting better.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: Disney-Pixar's Coco was more enjoyable three years ago when it was titled The Book of Life and came from Twentieth Century Fox.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: Twin touchstones from two of the most famous all-American flicks of the '80s feel like Pixar ensuring that audiences will feel at home in this foreign land.
reviews.author: Amy Nicholson

reviews.text: Coco is a lovely film, with fizzy songs sure to resonate with the small-fry and empowering messages about following dreams and helping friends. It's also explosively colourful, and beautifully rendered.
reviews.author: Kim Hughes

reviews.text: Adrian Molina and Matthew Aldrich's screenplay constantly surprises with its inspirations...
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: Luckily for the audience, the animation is Pixar perfect and stunning to behold. And there are enough visual skeleton gags to distract children in the audience from the fact that story is somewhat hard to follow.
reviews.author: Michael Heaton

reviews.text: Not only is it a wholly original story, but it also honors a culture that's so often overlooked by the movie industry. That alone might have made it a hit, but Coco has so much more to offer.
reviews.author: Stephanie Merry

reviews.text: Every step of the way in Coco is a visual and sonic delight.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: The script's ghoulish touches and mordant flashes of wit turn out to be its most disarming qualities.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: Dazzling visuals along with intricately structured and deeply moving storytelling are the hallmarks of the best of the studio's animated movies. "Coco" has those in spades ...
reviews.author: Soren Andersen

reviews.text: Coco's heart is its ethnicity.
reviews.author: Kirk Baird

reviews.text: Being Pixar, the picture looks wonderful - lighting cinematographer Danielle Fienberg has outshone herself - but in the end, the derivative Coco lacks the spark of life found in The Book of Life.
reviews.author: Sherilyn Connelly

reviews.text: Once again, Pixar delivers the most delightfuland insightful family movie of the season.
reviews.author: Mara Reinstein

reviews.text: An earnest, values-based story that doesn't sacrifice entertainment value.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: At various moments, Coco is simply the most beautiful film Pixar has ever made, each shot a striking work of art.
reviews.author: Josh Spiegel

reviews.text: Coco gets better as it goes, growing into something stranger and more resonant than its boy's-adventure setup suggests.
reviews.author: Alan Scherstuhl

reviews.text: Purgatorial politics aside, the story is actually a sweet meditation on family and destiny, and the ways in which one can trump the other.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: Coco may not represent Disney/Pixar at its pinnacle but it's close enough to the top to warrant consideration as the best computer-drawn film of 2017.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: "Coco" uses the vibrant colors and style of the holiday to spin an imaginative tale rich in tradition and culture, while beautifully celebrating family.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: "Coco" may not reach the Pixar heights, but there's an upside to its narrative density and elaborations: Since the movie's beautiful, a second viewing will not be difficult.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: ... while Coco brings a lot of sweetness and light with it (and, undoubtedly, a lot of happy tears), not one story beat includes something to startle the adults in the audience into realizing something new.
reviews.author: Alissa Wilkinson

reviews.text: It's not a subtle movie, but it's an uncommonly affecting one-a film that, like Pixar's best, manages to be whimsical and bone-deep, all at once.
reviews.author: Hillary Busis

reviews.text: This colorful tale of life, death and remembrance reanimates the heartstrings and secures a spot as the perfect holiday film.
reviews.author: Kristen Lopez

reviews.text: Maybe it really is never too late to forgive and celebrate life.
reviews.author: Sr. Rose Pacatte

reviews.text: In general Coco is the kind of first-rate technical production you expect from Pixar. On the other hand, it often feels more frantic than exciting, and it counts on moments of humor that often do not materialize.
reviews.author: Gary Thompson

reviews.text: This film is a classic.
reviews.author: Matt Zoller Seitz

reviews.text: If "Coco" doesn't quite reach the highest level of Pixar masterpieces, it plays a time-tested tune with captivating originality and flair, and with roving, playful pop-culture erudition.
reviews.author: A.O. Scott

reviews.text: Coco is a positively dazzling and deeply touching visual spectacle the likes of which is light years beyond Pixar's most recent, already extraordinary work.
reviews.author: David Medsker

reviews.text: "Coco" is a day-glo firecracker celebrating a country and a culture that has been (and continues to be) much maligned, and it's at its most vibrant when it journeys into and beyond the shadow of death.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: The Best Animated Film of 2017.
reviews.author: Scott Menzel

reviews.text: A story that will be universally adored.
reviews.author: Jason Guerrasio

reviews.text: Coco is ironically a refreshing and daring break from tradition.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: The joyful journey is Pixar's best effort since 2015's Inside Out and, like the studio's greatest works, makes you laugh and cry in equal doses.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: There's a trademark slickness that sells it and while recognizable tropes are present, there's something warm and comforting about their familiarity, and it helps that they play out within such fantastical, fresh-feeling surroundings.
reviews.author: Benjamin Lee

reviews.text: Guitar strings and heartstrings are equally and authentically plucked in exuberant fashion.
reviews.author: Jordan Ruimy

reviews.text: Coco makes sure to cross every item off its Mexican checklist -- tamales, sombreros, a shot of what looks like tequila -- but that's not the same as immersing us in a culture.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: The best moments in Coco are the less splendiferous, more solemn segments, especially the loving exchanges between Miguel and his great-grandmother Mama Coco, when the Pixar magic truly unfolds and our tear ducts get a good workout.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: Effortlessly gliding between kid-friendly spectacle and heart-tugging emotion by way of surrealist touches and a hilariously specific recurring joke about Frida Kahlo's unibrow, Coco is a goofy joy from start to finish.
reviews.author: Philip De Semlyen

reviews.text: Coco belongs to Pixar's elite class with a sweet, sophisticated family tale that knocks down imaginary walls between generations (and cultures) with dignity.
reviews.author: Tomris Laffly

reviews.text: An exhilarating and enchanting adventure with just the right blend of humor and heart. A perfect holiday treat for the entire family!
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: Everything in the movie is impeccable-the animation, settings, acting, pacing, music, emotions, humor.
reviews.author: Daniel Eagan

reviews.text: Coco is packed with terrific original tunes.
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: What kids, and yes, adults, too, will respond to is the eye-popping color, fast pace, music and the humor. But don't forget, parents, that this is a movie about death. Coco doesn't shy away from it, and there are sad moments, too.
reviews.author: Maren Longbella

reviews.text: Mexican lore and culture spring to life in this dazzling and delightful animated spectacle.
reviews.author: Roger Tennis

reviews.text: As a film, Coco delights the eye and squeezes the heart. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Daniel Krauze

reviews.text: Coco is a delight from start to finish, and a welcome return to form for Pixar, as this is probably the animation studio's best outing since 2015's Inside Out.
reviews.author: Don Kaye

reviews.text: After spinning its wheels with Cars 3, Pixar is back in top form with Coco, a delightful and moving mix of fantasy and family concerns.
reviews.author: Michael Gingold

reviews.text: An absolute joy to watch. Coco proves that Pixar is still at its best when tacking new ideas, rather than going back to the well.
reviews.author: Dirk Libbey

reviews.text: Bursting with bold colors and packing an emotional punch in the final moments that could make even the most jaded among you shed a tear, Coco is truly transcendent.
reviews.author: Matt Shiverdecker

reviews.text: "Coco" is full of life, especially when we're hanging out the with the dead.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: What a joy to watch "Coco," filmmaking that actively sandbags the viewer, with the emotions of a starving artist and the mind of a pool hustler.
reviews.author: Peter Hartlaub

reviews.text: "Coco" doesn't fully scale the heights of its predecessors, but where it counts, the movie hits almost all the right notes.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: The movie slips into a familiar rut and the scenery fades into the background.
reviews.author: Sam Adams

reviews.text: Miguel's wondrous adventure transports the audience too, to a place that reminds us of the irreplaceable value of those we love and the bonds that endure long after we're gone.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: One might argue that Coco could stand to be weirder and more self-indulgent; the alternate reality it creates is entertaining and expansive. But then it wouldn't be a Pixar film.
reviews.author: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky

reviews.text: a giddy, emotionally satisfying adventure popping with color and animation so breathtaking it's often photo realistic.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: The film brings Pixar's customary emotional directness to a festive, reverent, and wide-ranging pastiche of Mexican culture.
reviews.author: Keith Watson

reviews.text: "Coco" is a beautiful movie, and the ending is sure to reduce most viewers to pudding, but it also serves as a reminder of Pixar's free-range imagination when they step away from formula and sequels.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: Coco celebrates Mexico, its people and traditions, and flows easily between English and Spanish.
reviews.author: Clint O'Connor

reviews.text: Stunningly animated, poignant tribute to family and culture.
reviews.author: Sandie Angulo Chen

reviews.text: Pixar has another winner on its hand.
reviews.author: Joanne Soh

reviews.text: Coco is as indebted to Ratatouille as it is to Studio Ghibli's Spirited Away, but the combination of sensibilities and the colorful, semi-spooky milieu of the afterlife realm where most of the film is set is not at all unwelcome.
reviews.author: Emily Yoshida

reviews.text: While Pixar's glory days may be behind it, their spirit lives on in the vibrant, emotional Coco.
reviews.author: Matt Goldberg

reviews.text: An insta-classic, a dazzling, captivatingly written adventure resonating with profundity about life and death, memory and legacy. Graceful, bittersweet and altogether astonishing, "Coco" understands with utmost clarity what it means to be human.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: The naked desperation of the skeleton characters provides the heart and soul of the movie, and it's genuinely touching to see Miguel partner up with family members he either misses or never got to meet.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: It's consistently sweet, often funny, occasionally startling, and armed with some tremendously catchy tunes.
reviews.author: Michael Arbeiter

reviews.text: Coco shows more life in death than 99% of movies today, which should come as no surprise as Pixar once again aims directly for the heart.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: Coco is a heartwarming story about family and a well-crafted coming of age tale steeped beautifully in the traditions of Mexico's Día de los Muertos.
reviews.author: Molly Freeman

reviews.text: It doesn't reach the emotional heights of stand-alones like Up or WALL-E... But it's a tidy, endearing story with a beautiful, well-realized aesthetic, and marquee billing for culture that doesn't get a lot of that in American media.
reviews.author: Susana Polo

reviews.text: The results are magical and feel somewhat rebellious given the current political climate, which makes the film feel even more special.
reviews.author: Drew Taylor

reviews.text: Coco has become an endearing film for many Mexicans. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Lucero Calderón

reviews.text: It's fun, colorful and has a good story. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Carlos Díaz Reyes

reviews.text: Coco draws attention from the start with extraordinary visual and sound design. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Hugo Hernández Valdivia

reviews.text: Coco is undoubtedly a love letter to [Mexico]. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Rafael Rosales Santos

reviews.text: While it's not as profound as other works of the studio, CoCo exposes existential situations. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Adrián Ruiz

synopsis: Despite his family's generations-old ban on music, young Miguel dreams of becoming an accomplished musician like his idol Ernesto de la Cruz. Desperate to prove his talent, Miguel finds himself in the stunning and colorful Land of the Dead. After meeting a charming trickster named Héctor, the two new friends embark on an extraordinary journey to unlock the real story behind Miguel's family history.
